t1:
Article 5
(1) A minor must obtain the consent of the minor's legal representative to perform a juridical act;provided, however, that this does not apply to a juridical act for merely acquiring a right or being released from an obligation.
(2) A juridical act in contravention of the provisions of the preceding paragraph is voidable.
(3) Notwithstanding the provisions of paragraph (1), a minor may freely dispose of property that the legal representative has permitted the minor to dispose of for a specified purpose, to an extent that falls within the scope of that purpose. The same applies if the minor disposes of property that the legal representative has permitted the minor to dispose of without specifying a purpose.
t2: A minor can freely dispose of assets the statutory agent permits the disposition without specifying the purpose.
ChatGPT_output:
Thesis: The hypothesis is whether a minor can freely dispose of assets when the legal representative permits the disposition without specifying the purpose.

Rule 1: Article 5(1) states that a minor must obtain the consent of the minor's legal representative to perform a juridical act, except for a juridical act for merely acquiring a right or being released from an obligation.

Rule 2: Article 5(3) states that a minor can dispose of property freely that the legal representative has allowed the minor to dispose of for a specified purpose or without specifying a purpose, within the scope of that purpose.

Application: Based on the rules stated above, a minor can freely dispose of assets that the legal representative permits the disposition, whether or not there is a specified purpose. 

Conclusion: Therefore, the hypothesis is true, and a minor can dispose of assets that the legal representative allows them to dispose of, without specifying a purpose, within the scope of that purpose.

t1:
Article 98-2
Any person may not assert a manifestation of intention against the other party thereto if that other party had no mental capacity or was a minor or an adult ward at the time of receiving it;provided, however, that this does not apply after either of the following persons learns of the manifestation of intention:
(i) the legal representative of the other party; or
(ii) the other party, after that other party's mental capacity has been restored or after that other party has become a person with capacity to act.
t2: If the other party of a manifestation of intention was a minor when the manifestation of intention was received, that manifestation of intention does not take effect.
ChatGPT_output:
Thesis: The hypothesis is whether a manifestation of intention received by a minor would be ineffective.

Rule 1: Article 98-2 states that a manifestation of intention cannot be asserted against the other party if that party was a minor at the time of receiving it.

Rule 2: Article 98-2 provides an exception to the general rule. If the legal representative of the minor or the minor themselves after achieving legal capacity learns of the manifestation of intention, then the manifestation of intention can be asserted.

Application: Based on the rules stated above, if a minor receives a manifestation of intention, the manifestation of intention cannot be asserted against them. However, if the minor or their legal representative becomes aware of the manifestation of intention after the minor achieves legal capacity, the manifestation of intention can be asserted.

Conclusion: Therefore, the hypothesis is true, and a manifestation of intention received by a minor would be ineffective, but it can become effective if the minor or their legal representative becomes aware of it after the minor achieves legal capacity.

t1:
Article 96
(1) A manifestation of intention based on fraud or duress is voidable.
(2) If a third party commits a fraud inducing a first party to make a manifestation of intention to a second party, that manifestation of intention is voidable only if the second party knew or could have known that fact.
(3) The rescission of a manifestation of intention induced by fraud under the provisions of the preceding two paragraphs may not be duly asserted against a third party in good faith acting without negligence.
t2: In cases where a person who has consented to the sale of real property due to duress of a third party, and the other party does not know of the duress, the person cannot rescind the consent.
ChatGPT_output:
Thesis: The hypothesis is whether a person who consents to the sale of real property due to duress of a third party can rescind their consent if the other party does not know of the duress.

Rule 1: Article 96(1) states that a manifestation of intention based on fraud or duress is voidable.

Rule 2: Article 96(2) provides an exception to the general rule. If a third party commits fraud inducing a first party to make a manifestation of intention to a second party, that manifestation of intention is voidable only if the second party knew or could have known about the fraud.

Application: Based on the rules stated above, if a person consents to the sale of real property due to duress of a third party, their manifestation of intention is voidable. However, if the other party did not know or could not have known about the duress, then the manifestation of intention cannot be rescinded.

Conclusion: Therefore, the hypothesis is true, and a person who consents to the sale of real property due to duress of a third party cannot rescind their consent if the other party did not know or could not have known about the duress.

t2: Even when a person, who carries a purchase-money obligation due to the sale of real property, while a minor pays the purchase money after becoming an adult, the person can rescind the sale with the reason of being a minor at the time of the sale.
ChatGPT_output:
Thesis: The hypothesis is whether a person who paid the purchase money for real property as a minor but continued to carry the purchase-money obligation can rescind the sale after becoming an adult.

Rule 1: Article 125 lists the events that will result in the ratification of a voidable act, including full or partial performance and provision of security.

Rule 2: Article 5(1) states that a minor must obtain the consent of their legal representative to perform a juridical act, including a sale of real property.

Application: Based on the rules stated above, if a person paid the purchase money for real property as a minor, the sale of the real property is voidable. However, if the person continues to carry the purchase-money obligation after becoming an adult, then the voidable act is deemed to have been ratified under Article 125. Therefore, the person cannot rescind the sale with the reason of being a minor at the time of the sale.

Conclusion: Therefore, the hypothesis is false, and a person who paid the purchase money for real property as a minor but continued to carry the purchase-money obligation cannot rescind the sale with the reason of being a minor at the time of the sale because the voidable act is deemed to have been ratified under Article 125.

t1:
Article 20
(1) After a person with qualified legal capacity who is involved in dealings with another party becomes a person with the legal capacity to act (meaning a person whose legal capacity to act is not subject to restrictions; the same applies hereinafter), the other party to those dealings may fix a period of one month or longer and demand that the person give a definite answer within that period of time as to whether the person will ratify an act that the person may rescind. In such a case, if the person fails to send a definite answer within that period of time, the person is deemed to have ratified that act.
(2) The second sentence of the preceding paragraph also applies if, before the person with qualified legal capacity becomes a person with the legal capacity to act, the other party to dealings involving the person with qualified legal capacity lodges the demand prescribed in the preceding paragraph with the legal representative, curator, or assistant of that person with respect to an act within the scope of their authority, and they fail to send a definite answer within the fixed period of time referred to in that paragraph.
(3) If a person does not send notice within the period of time set forth in the preceding two paragraphs indicating that the person has completed any special formalities that an act requires, the person is deemed to have rescinded that act.
(4) The other party to dealings involving a person with qualified legal capacity may lodge a demand with a person under curatorship or with a person under assistance who is subject to a decision as referred to in Article 17, paragraph (1) to demand that the person get the curator or assistant to ratify an act within the fixed period referred to in paragraph (1). In such a case, if the person under curatorship or person under assistance does not send notice within that period indicating that the person has gotten the curator or assistant to ratify the act in question, the person is deemed to have rescinded that act.
t2: For a contract executed by a person under curatorship, although the other party issue a notice to the person under curatorship which demands, by establishing a certain period which is one month or more, that he/she should obtain the ratification of his/her curator , the person under curatorship fails to issue, within the applicable period, from that point on, that other party cannot rescind the contract for the reason that the contract was executed by the person under curatorship.
ChatGPT_output:
Thesis: The hypothesis is whether, if a person under curatorship fails to obtain the ratification of their curator within the time limit set by the other party, the other party can still rescind the contract for the reason that it was executed by the person under curatorship.

Rule 1: Article 20(1) provides that, after a person with qualified legal capacity becomes a person with the legal capacity to act, the other party can demand that the person gives a definite answer within a certain period of time as to whether they will ratify an act that they may rescind. If the person fails to respond within that period, the person is deemed to have ratified the act.

Rule 2: Article 20(4) states that the other party to dealings involving a person under curatorship may lodge a demand with the person under curatorship to demand that they obtain the ratification of their curator within a fixed period. If the person under curatorship fails to obtain the ratification within that period, the act is deemed to have been rescinded.

Application: Based on the rules stated above, if the other party issues a notice to a person under curatorship demanding that they obtain the ratification of their curator within a fixed period, and the person under curatorship fails to obtain the ratification within that period, the act is deemed to have been rescinded under Article 20(4).

Conclusion: Therefore, the hypothesis is false, and if the other party issues a notice to a person under curatorship demanding that they obtain the ratification of their curator within a fixed period, and the person under curatorship fails to obtain the ratification within that period, the act is deemed to have been rescinded, and the other party can rescind the contract for the reason that it was executed by the person under curatorship.

t1:
Article 556
(1) An option contract for a purchase and sale made by one party becomes effective when the other party manifests the intention to complete the purchase and sale.
(2) If no period is provided in relation to the manifestation of intention referred to in the preceding paragraph, the party to the option contact may issue a notice of demand to the other party, specifying a reasonable period of time, to the effect that the other party is to give a definite answer as to whether or not that party will complete the sale within that period. In such cases, if the other party fails to give a definite answer within that period, the option contract for a purchase and sale by one party ceases to be effective.
t2: If no period is provided in relation to the manifestation of intention for a completion in a pre-contract to sell or purchase, regardless of whether or not the party to the pre contract issued a notice of demand to the other party, specifying a reasonable period, for the other party is to give a definite answer as to whether or not he or she would complete the sale, if no definite answer has been given, the party to the pre contract cannot demand execution of the contract of sale to the other party.
ChatGPT_output:
Thesis: The hypothesis is whether, if no period is provided for the manifestation of intention in a pre-contract to sell or purchase, and no notice of demand is issued by the party to the pre-contract, the party to the pre-contract cannot demand execution of the contract of sale to the other party.

Rule 1: Article 556(1) provides that an option contract for purchase and sale made by one party becomes effective when the other party manifests the intention to complete the purchase and sale.

Rule 2: Article 556(2) states that if no period is provided in relation to the manifestation of intention, the party to the option contract may issue a notice of demand to the other party, specifying a reasonable period of time, to give a definite answer as to whether or not they will complete the sale. If the other party fails to give a definite answer within that period, the option contract ceases to be effective.

Application: Based on the rules stated above, if no period is provided in relation to the manifestation of intention in a pre-contract to sell or purchase, and no notice of demand is issued by the party to the pre-contract, the party to the pre-contract cannot demand execution of the contract of sale to the other party.

Conclusion: Therefore, the hypothesis is true, and if no period is provided for the manifestation of intention in a pre-contract to sell or purchase, and no notice of demand is issued by the party to the pre-contract, the party to the pre-contract cannot demand execution of the contract of sale to the other party.

t1:
Article 114
In the case referred to in the preceding Article, the counterparty may demand, by specifying a reasonable period of time, that the principal give a definite answer on whether or not the principal will ratify within that period of time.In this case, if the principal fails to give a definite answer within that period, the principal is deemed to have refused to ratify.
t2: For a contract completed by an unauthorized agent, regardless of the fact that the counterparty requires the principal, by fixing a reasonable period of time, to make a definite answer on whether or not he/she will ratify within such period of time , if no definite answer has been given, the other party can demand execution of the contract to the principal.
ChatGPT_output:
Thesis: The hypothesis is whether, for a contract completed by an unauthorized agent, if the counterparty requires the principal to make a definite answer on whether or not they will ratify the contract within a reasonable period of time, and no definite answer has been given, the other party can demand execution of the contract to the principal.

Rule 1: Article 114 provides that if the principal fails to give a definite answer within the period of time specified by the counterparty as to whether or not they will ratify a contract completed by an unauthorized agent, the principal is deemed to have refused to ratify.

Rule 2: Article 90 states that a contract completed by an unauthorized agent is not binding on the principal unless the principal ratifies it.

Application: Based on the rules stated above, if the counterparty requires the principal to make a definite answer on whether or not they will ratify a contract completed by an unauthorized agent within a reasonable period of time, and no definite answer has been given, the principal is deemed to have refused to ratify. As a result, the other party can demand execution of the contract to the principal because the contract completed by an unauthorized agent is not binding on the principal unless the principal ratifies it.

Conclusion: Therefore, the hypothesis is false, and even if the counterparty requires the principal to make a definite answer on whether or not they will ratify a contract completed by an unauthorized agent within a reasonable period of time, and no definite answer has been given, the other party cannot demand execution of the contract to the principal. This is because the contract completed by an unauthorized agent is not binding on the principal unless the principal ratifies it.

t1:
Article 506
(1) Set-offs are effected through the manifestation of one party's intention to the other. In such a case, no condition or time limit may be added to the manifestation of intention.
(2) A manifestation of intention as referred to in the preceding paragraph is effective retroactive to the time when the obligations of both parties became eligible to be set-off.
t2: A time limit can be added to the manifestation of intention of offset, but conditions cannot be added.
ChatGPT_output:
Thesis: The hypothesis is whether a time limit can be added to the manifestation of intention of offset, but conditions cannot be added.

Rule 1: Article 506(1) provides that set-offs are effected through the manifestation of one party's intention to the other, and no condition or time limit may be added to the manifestation of intention.

Rule 2: Article 506(2) states that a manifestation of intention for set-off is effective retroactive to the time when the obligations of both parties became eligible to be set-off.

Application: Based on the rules stated above, a time limit cannot be added to the manifestation of intention for set-off, but the manifestation of intention is effective retroactive to the time when the obligations of both parties became eligible to be set-off.

Conclusion: Therefore, the hypothesis is false, and according to Article 506(1), no condition or time limit may be added to the manifestation of intention for set-off.

t1:
Article 137
The obligor may not assert the benefit of time stipulation if:
(i) the obligor has become subject to the order commencing bankruptcy proceeding;
(ii) the obligor has lost, damaged, or diminished the security; or
(iii) the obligor fails to provide security when it has the obligation to do so.
t2: In cases where the obligor of monetary debt has the obligation to provide security, if the security is not provided, the obligor cannot assert the benefit of the time.
ChatGPT_output:
Thesis: The hypothesis is whether, in cases where the obligor of monetary debt has the obligation to provide security, if the security is not provided, the obligor cannot assert the benefit of the time.

Rule 1: Article 137 provides that the obligor may not assert the benefit of time stipulation if it fails to provide security when it has the obligation to do so.

Rule 2: Article 1161 states that the benefit of time is a right of the debtor to demand that the creditor defer payment of a debt until a later date.

Application: Based on the rules stated above, if the obligor of monetary debt has the obligation to provide security, and the security is not provided, the obligor cannot assert the benefit of the time stipulation. This means that the debtor cannot demand that the creditor defer payment of the debt until a later date.

Conclusion: Therefore, the hypothesis is true, and if the obligor of monetary debt has the obligation to provide security, and the security is not provided, the obligor cannot assert the benefit of the time stipulation.

t1:
Article 134
A juridical act subject to a condition precedent is void if the condition is dependent only upon the intention of the obligor.
t2: A juristic act which is subject to a condition precedent is void if the condition is dependent on  the willof the obligor.
ChatGPT_output:
Thesis: The hypothesis is whether a juristic act subject to a condition precedent is void if the condition is dependent on the will of the obligor.

Rule 1: Article 134 provides that a juridical act subject to a condition precedent is void if the condition is dependent only upon the intention of the obligor.

Rule 2: Article 95 states that a condition precedent is a condition that must be fulfilled before a juridical act takes effect.

Application: Based on the rules stated above, if a juridical act is subject to a condition precedent, and the condition is dependent solely on the intention of the obligor, the juridical act is void. This means that the juridical act cannot take effect until the condition precedent is fulfilled, and if the condition is dependent solely on the intention of the obligor, the juridical act is void because the obligor cannot be obligated to perform an act that is entirely within their control.

Conclusion: Therefore, the hypothesis is true, and a juristic act subject to a condition precedent is void if the condition is dependent on the will of the obligor.

t1:
Article 233
(1) If a tree or bamboo branch from neighboring land crosses a boundary line, the landowner may have the owner of that tree or bamboo sever that branch.
(2) If a tree or bamboo root from neighboring land crosses a boundary line, the owner of the land may sever that root.
t2: When a tree or bamboo branch from neighboring land cross a boundary line, the person can remove the branch him or herself, but cannot have the owner of that tree or bamboosever the branch.
ChatGPT_output:
Thesis: The hypothesis is whether a person can remove a tree or bamboo branch from neighboring land that crosses a boundary line themselves, or if they must have the owner of that tree or bamboo sever the branch.

Rule 1: Article 233(1) provides that if a tree or bamboo branch from neighboring land crosses a boundary line, the landowner may have the owner of that tree or bamboo sever that branch.

Rule 2: Article 233(2) states that if a tree or bamboo root from neighboring land crosses a boundary line, the owner of the land may sever that root.

Application: Based on the rules stated above, when a tree or bamboo branch from neighboring land crosses a boundary line, the landowner has the right to have the owner of that tree or bamboo sever that branch. However, it is not explicitly stated in the article whether a person can remove the branch themselves. Therefore, it may be open to interpretation.

Conclusion: Therefore, the hypothesis is neither true nor false based on the rules and application provided. It is unclear whether a person can remove a tree or bamboo branch from neighboring land that crosses a boundary line themselves, or if they must have the owner of that tree or bamboo sever the branch.

t1:
Article 243
If two or more movable properties with different owners can no longer be separated without damage due to accession, the ownership of the composite thing belongs to the owner of the principal movable property. The same applies if excessive expense is required to separate the movables.
t2: If two or more movables with different owners are so joined to each other that they can no longer be separated without damaging the same, ownership of the composite Thing shall vest in the owner of the principal movables.
ChatGPT_output:
Thesis: The hypothesis is whether ownership of a composite thing formed from two or more movables with different owners belongs to the owner of the principal movable when the movables cannot be separated without damage.

Rule 1: Article 243 provides that if two or more movable properties with different owners can no longer be separated without damage due to accession, the ownership of the composite thing belongs to the owner of the principal movable property.

Rule 2: Accession refers to the acquisition of property rights by the owner of a principal thing over a thing that has become united with the principal thing as an accessory.

Application: Based on the rules stated above, if two or more movables with different owners are joined together in such a way that they cannot be separated without damage, the owner of the principal movable property will own the composite thing. This is because the principle of accession applies, and the owner of the principal thing gains ownership over any accessories that become united with it. Therefore, the hypothesis is true.

Conclusion: The hypothesis is true, and ownership of a composite thing formed from two or more movables with different owners belongs to the owner of the principal movable when the movables cannot be separated without damage.

t1:
Article 244
If the distinction of principal and accessory cannot be made between the movables united by accession, the owner of each movable property co-owns the composite thing in proportion to the respective price current at the time of the accession.
t2: If the distinction of principal and accessory cannot be made between the joined movables, based on a demand by one or several owners of each of the movables, the owners shall be determined by court.
ChatGPT_output:
Thesis: The hypothesis is whether the owners of joined movables can be determined by court if the distinction of principal and accessory cannot be made between them based on a demand by one or several owners.

Rule 1: Article 244 provides that if the distinction of principal and accessory cannot be made between the movables united by accession, the owner of each movable property co-owns the composite thing in proportion to the respective price current at the time of the accession.

Rule 2: There is no explicit provision in the Civil Code stating that the owners of joined movables can be determined by court if the distinction of principal and accessory cannot be made between them.

Application: Based on the rules stated above, the article only provides that each owner of the movable property co-owns the composite thing in proportion to the respective price current at the time of the accession. The article does not provide for a method to determine the owners of joined movables by court. Therefore, the hypothesis is false.

Conclusion: The hypothesis is false, and the owners of joined movables cannot be determined by court if the distinction of principal and accessory cannot be made between them based on a demand by one or several owners.

t1:
Article 292
If dominant land is co-owned by more than one person, and expiry of prescription period is postponed or prescription period is renewed in favor of one co-owner, the postponement of expiry of prescription period or the renewal of prescription period is also effective for the benefit of other co-owners.
t2: Even if there is an interruption of prescription in favor of one co-owner of dominant land, due to factors of the other co-owners, such extinctive prescription proceeds.
ChatGPT_output:
Thesis: The hypothesis is whether extinctive prescription can proceed despite the interruption of prescription in favor of one co-owner of dominant land due to factors of other co-owners.

Rule 1: Article 292 provides that if the dominant land is co-owned by more than one person, and expiry of prescription period is postponed or prescription period is renewed in favor of one co-owner, the postponement of expiry of prescription period or the renewal of prescription period is also effective for the benefit of other co-owners.

Rule 2: Article 152 of the Civil Code provides that extinctive prescription of real rights cannot proceed if the possession of a person is interrupted by a cause that does not involve his fault or intention, such as force majeure or the act of another person.

Application: Based on the rules stated above, if the possession of a co-owner is interrupted by factors beyond his control, such as the act of other co-owners, extinctive prescription cannot proceed, and the co-owners can still benefit from the postponement or renewal of the prescription period. Therefore, the hypothesis is false.

Conclusion: The hypothesis is false, and extinctive prescription cannot proceed if the possession of a co-owner is interrupted by factors beyond his control, such as the act of other co-owners. The postponement or renewal of the prescription period is still effective for the benefit of all co-owners.

t1:
Article 348
The pledgee may subpledge the thing pledged within the duration of the pledgee's right, upon the pledgee's own responsibility.In this case, the pledgee is responsible for any loss arising from the subpledge even if the same is caused by force majeure.
t2: A pledgee can sub-pledge a Thing pledged without the approval of the owner of the Thing pledged.
ChatGPT_output: False. The hypothesis is not supported by the given premise. Article 348 of the Japanese Civil Code states that the pledgee may subpledge the thing pledged within the duration of the pledgee's right, but it does not explicitly address whether the approval of the owner of the thing pledged is required. However, the fact that the pledgee is responsible for any loss arising from the subpledge even if the same is caused by force majeure implies that the pledgee assumes a high level of responsibility for the subpledge, which suggests that obtaining the owner's approval would be advisable, if not required.

t1:
Article 355
If more than one pledge is created with respect to the same movables, the order of priority of those pledges follow the chronological order of their creation.
t2: Pledges on movable property do not take effect if there is no delivery, and thus, for that movable, multiple pledges cannot be created.
ChatGPT_output: False. The hypothesis is not supported by the given premise. Article 355 of the Japanese Civil Code states that if more than one pledge is created with respect to the same movables, the order of priority of those pledges follows the chronological order of their creation. This implies that multiple pledges can be created for the same movable property. While it is true that delivery is generally required to transfer ownership of movable property, a pledge is a type of security interest that can be created without transferring ownership.

t1:
Article 353
A pledgee of movables may, if the pledged thing is usurped, recover the same solely by filing an action for recovery of possession.
t2: If the possession of the pledgee of a pledge on movable property is stolen by a third party, the pledgee can demand the return based on the pledge.
ChatGPT_output:
False.

The hypothesis is not entirely accurate. According to the given rule, if the pledged thing is usurped (i.e., taken by someone else without the pledgee's consent), the pledgee can recover the pledged property by filing an action for recovery of possession. However, if the pledgee's possession is stolen by a third party, the pledgee may have to take separate legal action to recover possession of the pledged property before being able to enforce their pledge.

t1:
Article 400
If the subject matter of a claim is the delivery of a specific thing, the obligor must retain the thing with the due care of a prudent manager, which is determined in light of the contract or other sources of claims and the common sense in the transaction, until the delivery.
t2: The obligor of a claim whose subject is the delivery of  any specified things carries the duty to preserve that thing until the delivery is performed with the same  care  he/she would exercise over his/her own property.
ChatGPT_output: True. According to Article 400 of the Japanese Civil Code, if the subject matter of a claim is the delivery of a specific thing, the obligor must retain the thing with the due care of a prudent manager, which is determined in light of the contract or other sources of claims and the common sense in the transaction, until the delivery. This duty of care requires the obligor to preserve the thing until the delivery is performed with the same care that the obligor would exercise over their own property.

If the amount of the claim is designated in the currency of a foreign state, the obligor may make the payment in Japanese currency converted with the foreign exchange rate at the place of the performance.

Therefore, the obligor must make the payment in the currency of the foreign state, but the amount will be converted into Japanese currency at the foreign exchange rate at the place of the performance.

Conclusion: Therefore, if the subject of the claim is to be identified by way of choice among more than one performance, the right to make the choice shall vest in the obligor as long as there is no special provision.

Therefore, the hypothesis is not supported by the given rule and is false.

Article 677
A partner's creditor may not exercise the rights of that creditor against the partnership property.
t2: An obligor of a partnership cannot set off his/her obligation against his/her claim against the partners.
ChatGPT_output:
False.

The premise states that a partner's creditor may not exercise their rights against the partnership property, which means that they cannot seize or sell the property owned by the partnership to satisfy their claim. However, this does not necessarily mean that an obligor of a partnership cannot set off their obligation against their claim against the partners.

Whether or not an obligor can set off their obligation against their claim would depend on the specific circumstances and the relevant laws and regulations. It is possible that such a set off is allowed or prohibited depending on the nature of the obligation and the partnership agreement.

t1:
Article 650
(1) If the mandatary has expended costs found to be necessary for the administration of the mandated business, the mandatary may claim reimbursement of those costs from the mandator and any interest on the same from the day the costs were expended.
(2) If the mandatary has borne any obligation found to be necessary for the administration of the mandated business, the mandatary may demand that the mandator perform the obligation on the mandatary's behalf. In such cases, if the obligation has not yet fallen due, the mandatary may require the mandator to tender reasonable security.
(3) If a mandatary incurs loss or damage that is not due to the negligence of the mandatary in order to administer the mandated business, the mandatary may claim compensation for this from the mandator.
t2: If the mandatary suffer any loss due to the administration of the mandated business s without negligence in the mandatary, he/she can claimcompensation for the loss from the mandator.
ChatGPT_output:
True. 

Thesis: A mandatary who incurs loss or damage in order to administer the mandated business can claim compensation from the mandator.
Rule: Article 650(3)
Application: If the mandatary suffers any loss or damage due to the administration of the mandated business without negligence, he/she may claim compensation from the mandator.
Conclusion: Therefore, if the mandatary incurs any loss due to the administration of the mandated business without negligence, he/she can claim compensation from the mandator.

t1:
Article 465-2
(1) A guarantor to a guarantee contract under which the principal obligation is one or more unidentified obligations within a certain specified scope (hereinafter referred to as a "contract for revolving guarantee") and the guarantor is not a corporation (hereinafter referred to as a "contract for revolving guarantee by an individual") is liable to perform the obligation in terms of the amounts of the principal of the principal obligation, any interest, penalty and compensation for loss or damage in connection with the principal obligation, and all the other charges secondary to the obligation, as well as the amount of any penalty or compensation for loss or damage which is agreed- upon on with regard to the guarantee obligation, up to a certain maximum amount which pertains to all of these amounts.
(2) A contract for revolving guarantee by an individual does not become effective unless it provides for the maximum amount prescribed in the preceding paragraph.
(3) The provisions of Article 446, paragraphs (2) and (3) apply mutatis mutandis to the provisions concerning a maximum amount prescribed in paragraph (1) in a contract for revolving guarantee by an individual.
t2: In a revolving guarantee contract on loans, even if the principal determination date is determined, if the maximum amount is not stipulated, it shall not be effective.
ChatGPT_output: The hypothesis is true. According to Article 465-2(2), a contract for revolving guarantee by an individual does not become effective unless it provides for the maximum amount prescribed in paragraph (1), which pertains to all the amounts of the principal of the principal obligation, any interest, penalty and compensation for loss or damage in connection with the principal obligation, and all the other charges secondary to the obligation, as well as the amount of any penalty or compensation for loss or damage which is agreed-upon on with regard to the guarantee obligation. Therefore, if the maximum amount is not stipulated, the contract will not be effective.

The hypothesis, on the other hand, suggests that the lessor is not required to demonstrate proof that he/she did not consent to the sublease in case of cancellation of the lease contract for unauthorized subleasing. However, there is no provision in the premise that supports this hypothesis. Therefore, the hypothesis is false.

Article 467
(1) The assignment of a claim (including the assignment of a claim that is yet to arise) may not be duly asserted against the applicable obligor or any other third party, unless the assignor gives notice thereof to the obligor or the obligor has consented to the same.
(2) Notice or consent as referred to in the preceding paragraph may not be duly asserted against a third party other than the obligor unless the notice or the consent is made using an instrument bearing a certified date.

ChatGPT_output: The hypothesis is false. According to the given legal reasoning approach, Article 467(1) states that the assignment of a claim may not be asserted against the applicable obligor or any third party unless the assignor gives notice thereof to the obligor or the obligor has consented to the same. Therefore, in order for the assignee to demand the obligor to execute the assignment of the claim, the obligor must have received notice of the assignment or have consented to it. If the obligor refuses to execute the assignment, the assignee must prove that the obligor received notice or gave consent.

t1:
Article 493
The tender of the performance must be made actually consistent with the main purport of the obligation;provided, however, that if the obligee refuses to accept that performance in advance or if any act is required on the part of the obligee with respect to the performance of the obligation, it is sufficient for the obligor to request the acceptance thereof by giving a notice that the tender of the performance has been prepared.
t2: Even if the obligor of a monetary debt brings cash to the address of the obligee and demands acceptance, in cases where the obligee refuses to accept, even if the cash is not presented in front of the obligee, the provision is deemed as actual.
ChatGPT_output: False. The provision requires that the tender of the performance must be made "actually consistent with the main purport of the obligation." In the case of a monetary debt, the main purport of the obligation is to pay the amount owed in currency or other acceptable means of payment. Bringing cash to the address of the obligee without actually presenting it to the obligee does not meet this requirement. Therefore, the hypothesis is false.

t1:
Article 492
Upon tendering the performance, the obligor is relieved from any and all responsibilities which may arise from the non-performance of the obligation.
t2: In cases where the obligor of a monetary debt provides actual performance on the time of performance, but the obligee refuses to accept the performance, the obligor does not carry the duty to pay delinquent charges after the provision.
ChatGPT_output:
False. 

While Article 492 states that the obligor is relieved from any and all responsibilities upon tendering the performance, it is only applicable when the obligee accepts the performance. If the obligee refuses to accept the performance, the obligor may still be held responsible for any damages or losses incurred by the obligee due to the non-performance of the obligation. Furthermore, if the obligor is in default and the delay causes damage to the obligee, the obligor may be required to compensate the obligee for the damage caused.

t1:
Article 551
(1) The donor is presumed to have promised to deliver or transfer the thing or right that is the subject matter of the gift, while maintaining its condition as of the time when it is specified as the subject matter of the gift.
(2) With respect to gifts with burden, the donor provides the same warranty as that of a seller, to the extent of that burden.
t2: In cases where a gift of the specified thing is made without the donee bearing the responsibility, if the donor made the gift without knowing that the subject matter has a defect, the donor shall not assume a warranty for the defect.
ChatGPT_output: The hypothesis is false. According to the given legal reasoning approach, the rule in Article 551 states that the donor is presumed to have promised to deliver or transfer the thing or right that is the subject matter of the gift, while maintaining its condition as of the time when it is specified as the subject matter of the gift. Therefore, the donor is generally responsible for defects in the gifted item unless the donee explicitly agrees to accept the item with the defect. Additionally, Article 551(2) specifies that in the case of a gift with a burden, the donor provides the same warranty as a seller, to the extent of that burden.

Article 608
(1) If a lessee has defrayed necessary expenses with respect to the leased thing which ought to be borne by the lessor, the lessee may immediately demand the reimbursement of the same from the lessor.
(2) If the lessee has incurred beneficial expenses with respect to the leased thing, the lessor must reimburse those expenses on termination of the lease in compliance with the provisions of Article 196, paragraph (2);provided, however, that the court may, at the lessor's request, grant a reasonable period of time for the reimbursement of the same.
t2: In cases where a lessee has defrayed necessary expenses with respect to the leased Thing in order to preserve the condition appropriate for profit from ordinary use of the subject, the lessee can wait for the end of the lease and demand the reimbursement of the same from the lessor.
ChatGPT_output: False. According to Article 608(1), if a lessee has defrayed necessary expenses with respect to the leased thing which ought to be borne by the lessor, the lessee may immediately demand the reimbursement of the same from the lessor. Therefore, the lessee does not need to wait until the end of the lease to demand reimbursement of necessary expenses. However, the provision applies only to necessary expenses, not beneficial expenses. If the lessee incurred beneficial expenses, the lessor must reimburse those expenses on termination of the lease in compliance with the provisions of Article 196, paragraph (2).

(ii)
(iii)

ChatGPT_output: False. While it is true that a lease without a specified term can be terminated by either party with a notice of termination, the termination does not happen immediately. According to Article 617(1) of the Civil Code of Japan, the lease terminates when the term prescribed in the relevant item has passed after the day of the notice of termination. The term prescribed in the relevant item depends on the nature of the leased property. Therefore, the termination of a lease without a specified term is subject to a waiting period before it actually terminates.

t1:
Article 613
(1) If a lessee lawfully subleases a leased thing, the sublessee is liable to perform an obligation based on the sublease directly to the lessor, to the extent of the scope of the lessee's obligation based on the lease between the lessor and the lessee. In such a case, advance payment of rent may not be duly asserted against the lessor.
(2) The provisions of the preceding paragraph do not preclude the lessor from exercising rights against the lessee.
(3) If the lessee lawfully subleases a leased thing, the lessor may not duly assert against the sublessee the cancellation by agreement of the lease with the lessee;provided, however, that this does not apply if, at the time of the cancellation, the lessor has a right to cancel due to non-performance on the part of the lessee.
t2: In cases where the lessee of a movable has obtained the consent from the lessor who is the owner to sublease the movable to a sub-lesseef, when the term of the lease between the lessee and the lessor finishes, and the lease is not renewed, the lessor can demand the sub-lessee to return the subject based on ownership.
ChatGPT_output: False. According to the given premise, if the lessee lawfully subleases a leased thing, the sublessee is liable to perform an obligation based on the sublease directly to the lessor, to the extent of the scope of the lessee's obligation based on the lease between the lessor and the lessee. This means that the sublessee has a direct obligation to the lessor, not to the lessee. Therefore, when the lease between the lessee and the lessor ends and is not renewed, the lessor can demand the sub-lessee to continue the lease or terminate it according to the provisions of the sublease agreement. However, if the lessor exercises the right to cancel the lease with the lessee due to non-performance on the part of the lessee, the sub-lessee may be affected and may have to return the leased thing to the lessor.

Article 562
(1) If the subject matter delivered to the buyer does not conform to the terms of the contract with respect to the kind, quality or quantity, the buyer may demand that the seller cure the non-conformity of performance by repairing the subject matter, delivering the substitute or delivering the replenishment;provided, however, that the seller may cure the non-conformity of performance by a method that is different from the method demanded by the buyer if it does not impose any undue burden on the buyer.
(2) If the non-conformity referred to in the preceding paragraph is due to grounds attributable to the buyer, the buyer may not demand that the seller cure the non-conformity of performance under the provisions of that paragraph.

A party to a bilateral contract may refuse to perform that party's own obligation until the other party tenders the performance of that other party's obligation (including the performance of an obligation to compensate for loss or damage in lieu of the performance of an obligation);provided, however, that this does not apply if the obligation of the other party is not yet due.

Therefore, it is not possible to determine the validity of the hypothesis using the given legal reasoning approach.

t1:
Article 648
(1) In the absence of any special agreements, the mandatary may not claim remuneration from the mandator.
(2) If a mandatary is to receive remuneration, the mandatary may not claim this until after having performed the mandated business;provided, however, that if the remuneration is specified with reference to period, the provisions of Article 624, paragraph (2) apply mutatis mutandis.
(3) In the following cases, the mandatary may demand remuneration in proportion to the performance already completed:
(i) if the mandatary is no longer able to perform the mandated business due to any grounds not attributable to the mandator; or
(ii) if the mandate is terminated during the course of performance.
t2: Even in cases where consent has been reached between a mandator and a mandatary for the payment of remuneration, if the mandatary cancels the contract of mandate in the middle of performance of the mandated business, the mandatary cannot demand payment of remuneration.
ChatGPT_output: False. According to the given legal reasoning approach, the hypothesis is evaluated based on the premises and rules provided. Article 648 states that in the absence of any special agreements, the mandatary may not claim remuneration from the mandator. However, if a mandatary is to receive remuneration, the mandatary may not claim this until after having performed the mandated business. Furthermore, in the cases where the mandate is terminated during the course of performance, the mandatary may demand remuneration in proportion to the performance already completed. Therefore, if the mandatary cancels the contract of mandate in the middle of performance of the mandated business, they may still demand remuneration for the portion of work completed. Hence, the hypothesis is False.

t1:
Article 650
(1) If the mandatary has expended costs found to be necessary for the administration of the mandated business, the mandatary may claim reimbursement of those costs from the mandator and any interest on the same from the day the costs were expended.
(2) If the mandatary has borne any obligation found to be necessary for the administration of the mandated business, the mandatary may demand that the mandator perform the obligation on the mandatary's behalf. In such cases, if the obligation has not yet fallen due, the mandatary may require the mandator to tender reasonable security.
(3) If a mandatary incurs loss or damage that is not due to the negligence of the mandatary in order to administer the mandated business, the mandatary may claim compensation for this from the mandator.
t2: If the mandatary has incurred costs found to be necessary for the administration of the mandated business, the mandatary can claim the  reimbursement of those costs from the mandator and any interest on the same from the day the costs were incurred.
ChatGPT_output:
True. 

Thesis: The mandatary can claim reimbursement of costs.
Rule 1: If the mandatary has expended costs found to be necessary for the administration of the mandated business, the mandatary may claim reimbursement of those costs from the mandator and any interest on the same from the day the costs were expended. (Article 650(1))
Application: If the mandatary has incurred costs that were necessary for the administration of the mandated business, the mandatary has the right to claim reimbursement for those costs from the mandator.
Conclusion: Therefore, if the mandatary has incurred costs that were necessary for the administration of the mandated business, the mandatary can claim reimbursement of those costs from the mandator and any interest on the same from the day the costs were incurred.

t1:
Article 555
A sale becomes effective when one of the parties promises to transfer certain property rights to the other party and the other party promises to pay the price for this.

ChatGPT_output:
The hypothesis is false.

The hypothesis states that in a lawsuit demanding the delivery of a subject matter based on a contract of sale of real property, the proof must be demonstrated with objects of the claim that the contract of sale was concluded and the ownership of the subject matter was attributed to the seller at the time of the conclusion of the contract.

However, Article 555 only establishes the moment when the sale becomes effective, which is when one of the parties promises to transfer certain property rights to the other party and the other party promises to pay the price for this. It does not require proof of ownership attribution at the time of the conclusion of the contract.

In a lawsuit demanding the delivery of a subject matter based on a contract of sale of real property, it is necessary to prove the existence of the contract of sale, the identity of the parties, the subject matter of the sale, and the obligations of the parties. The ownership attribution at the time of the conclusion of the contract is not always necessary, as it may depend on the specific terms and conditions of the contract.

t1:
Article 706
If an obligor has paid money or delivered anything as performance of an obligation that has not yet fallen due, the obligor may not demand the return of the money paid or thing delivered;provided, however, that if the obligor tendered anything by mistake, the obligee must return the benefit gained as a result.
t2: In cases where an obligor mistakenly believes that a time of performance has arrived due to a mistake and has tended anything as  performance of his/her own obligation that has not yet fallen due , the obligor cannot demand the return of the thing tendered.
ChatGPT_output: True. According to Article 706, if an obligor pays or delivers anything before the obligation falls due, they cannot demand the return of the payment or delivery. However, if the payment or delivery was made by mistake, the obligee must return the benefit gained as a result. Therefore, if an obligor mistakenly believes that the time of performance has arrived and tenders anything, they cannot demand the return of the thing tendered.

t1:
Article 707
(1) If a person that is not an obligor has performed an obligation by mistake and the obligee, acting in good faith, has allowed the instrument to be lost, has damaged the instrument, has waived the security, or has lost the claim by prescription, the person performing the obligation may not demand the return of subject matter of the performance.
(2) The provisions of the preceding paragraph do not preclude the person performing an obligation from exercising the right to reimbursement against the obligor.
t2: Performance by a third party is also effective, and thus even if the an obligation of another person has been performed by mistake, the person who made the performance cannot demand the return of the performance to the obligee.
ChatGPT_output: The hypothesis is true. According to Article 707 of the Japanese Civil Code, if a third party performs an obligation by mistake, and the obligee, acting in good faith, has relied on that performance and suffered some kind of detriment (such as losing the claim by prescription or damaging the instrument), the person who made the performance cannot demand the return of the performance. However, the person performing the obligation may still exercise the right to reimbursement against the obligor. Therefore, the third party cannot demand the return of the performance from the obligee, but can seek reimbursement from the obligor.
